comments.body: is this actually based on the metric window?  if so, it should use the metric window reported by the custom metrics API, not be fixed in configuration.

I agree in principle. But that would be significantly more complicated (currently client doesn't return metric window so I would have to change client, add more tests, and modify existing tests).

I need to merge this in 2 days so I'd rather not do it in this PR. Can we settle for a TODO. I'd send a PR addressing the TODO when I'm back from vacation (and merge it after the freeze).
I guess we are not worried about backward compatibility issues here, right?
actually, the json name is the same. So, NVM.

No, we aren't. However, the JSON is backwards-compatible with this change.
This is all alpha, and we're trying to get to a state where we can move types out, do a full field-by-field review on everything, change stuff if needed and then graduate individual components' types to `v1beta1` and higher.
Sounds good. I already approved. Thanks!
why remove the tags?
see @liggitt's and my conversation in Slack and the PR description

the k-c-m structs had a mix of missing tags, incorrect tags, and correct tags, but it didn't really matter because those structs were not currently used for deserializing anything yet.

this tries to make it clear which structs are currently being used for serialization and which are free to be changed/corrected without regard for existing deserialization use

for k-c-m, we need to:
1. move structs to the right packages
2. pick the actual field names and structure to use, then add serialization tags (resulting in zero violations found by the verifier in the process)
4. add deserialization paths
these should probably end up in `controllermanager.config.k8s.io` under `pkg/controller/apis`, similar to kubelet. can you move them in a follow up?
yes i can
Question: How do we know which fields were optional in the flag based config? Are we relying on flag description?
Is this relative or absolute? If relative, is it resolved relative to the location of the file containing this config, or to the cwd of the kubelet process, or something else?
Same question goes for all file/dir/path fields
Why is this a pointer? Is it because is it is optional?

I'll have to ask @mikedanese to double check, but generally speaking we use a pointer for numeric values where 0 is a valid option but a poor default (nil then implies default behavior, instead of 0). In this case, my guess would be that we allow a user to set 0, but in most scenarios you would not want to place that tight of a restriction on old container instances.
Agree with @mtaufen. 0 is valid but not a good default.

We should really audit all these for optional values, and annotate them all with `omitempty` (see https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/docs/devel/api-conventions.md#optional-vs-required).

Any optional primitive field should really be a pointer, whether or not 0 is an acceptable default.
I think there's no reason to have the internal & external versions differ for the time being. Also, this should have `omitempty`.

@derekwaynecarr recently enabled eviction by default by setting the  `EvictionHard` threshold, so now `""` is no longer the correct default. But `""` is still a valid value, because, presumably, setting `""` is how you would disable eviction. So we need a pointer on the external. I can definitely add `omitempty` though.
Its weird to call this `Seconds`, when it takes a duration.  `iptablesSyncPeriod`?
Oh, comment doesn't match code.
This is actually confusing for me.  Do I use `kubeconfigPath` or `master`?  What if they disagree?

Also, this name should probably describe what its for.  For instance `masterKubeconfig`.  You're likely to end up with several of these in the various config types (we have three). Describing what it should point to is useful.

if paths are specified in config files, we need to decide how relative paths are resolved (currently it is resolved relative to the working directory of the process). Relative file references from config files should be resolved relative to the directory containing the config file. We came up with the following approach in OpenShift, where path resolution is an explicit operation invoked on a config object:

https://github.com/openshift/origin/blob/3cf7f3cccd5b7b95448568ba8e2b3c81cc6ab9af/pkg/cmd/server/api/helpers.go#L240-L268
That reminds me, we never came up with a way to allow env-var expansion inside of fields, but it would be convenient.
I think that `Period`s will serve you better than naming a specific unit.  It allows a consistent representation of durations across all fields.

Even though the bindAddress and bindPort are logically separate, its easier for users to describe them in a single field.  It's probably more natural for them to do `127.0.0.1:8443` and this config is for them not for us.
All optional fields need to have `omitempty`
